description: Variation of Conditions 2 (Approved drawings), 5 (Boundary treatment), and 7 (Hard and soft landscaping scheme) of the Planning Permission 19/01081/FUL (Erection of detached 1x 3 bedroom house) to relocate the cycle/waste storage providing access to residents and alterations to roof lights, changing the geometry and dimension of the new boundary and improving the quality of landscape layout.
decision_conditions: Development  shall  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  the  materials  specified  on  the approved plans and on the application form unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of the granting of planning application reference 19/01081/FUL.Reason:  As required  by Section 91 of  the Town  and Country Planning  Act  1990,  as amended by Section 51 of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in strict accordance with "Construction Management Plan" dated September 2019 (as approved by application reference 19/01920/COND) unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: In order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in strict accordance with "Appendix C - Levels Layout" (as approved by application reference 19/01920/COND) unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure that the appearance and functioning of the development is satisfactory and to safeguard the amenities of adjoining occupiers in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012 and comply with Supplementary Planning Document 'Access for All' (July 2005).

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in strict accordance with the approved landscaping scheme, which shall be implemented within the first planting season following substantial completion of the development. The tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority. Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced during the following planting season, and the areas shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose. Alterations to the landscaping scheme must be agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (or any Order revoking or re-enacting this Order) no windows or other openings (other than those hereby approved) shall be formed in the walls of the dwelling house hereby approved without the prior written consent of the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, evidence showing that the development has achieved at least a 19% improvement in CO2 emissions versus Part L of the Building Regulations and internal water usage rates of no greater than 105L per person per day have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation, in accordance with policy 5.2 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1, DM3 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in strict accordance with "Appendix C - Sustainable Drainage System Details and Management Plan" (as approved by application reference 19/01920/COND) unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To prevent the increased risk of flooding in accordance with Policy CS1 (Climate Change Mitigation) of the Local Development Framework Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.
E4 - Acoustic Conditions in Schools

The assessment of this application is based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. If it transpires that the drawings / plans submitted are incorrect this would nullify the validity of this decision and you are advised to submit a fresh application with the correct information / drawings.

The assessment of this application is based on measurements taken from the submitted drawings / plans. SiteThe application site is a two-storey semi-detached dwellinghouse located on Kings Drive. The site is not subject to any particular designations or environmental constraints.Planning History03/16295/FUL - Erection of two storey side extension incorporating garage and two storey rear extension. Application Granted on 21 Jul 2003. With conditions.Consultations15 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations were received.ConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: The impact of the development on character and appearance. The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.The impact of the development on fire safety. When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Comments: The application proposes the construction of an infill side roof extension above an existing two storey side extension, as well as the installation of 1 no. rooflight on the side roofslope. Whilst this extension would not strictly conform to the recommendations of the Residential Design SPD, Officers note that the extension would not be uncharacteristic of Kings Drive. As such, it is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

SiteThe application site is a two-storey detached dwellinghouse located on Woodlands Avenue. The site is located within The Berg Estate - Local Area of Special Character. Planning History4708/MC - Erection of bedroom over garage. Application Granted on 21 May 1964.Consultations6 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations were received.ConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: The impact of the development on character and appearance. The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.The impact of the development on heritage assets. The impact of the development on highways. The impact of the development on fire safety. When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Comments: The application proposes the construction of a single storey rear extension. This extension would measure a maximum of approximately 5.9 metres from the rear wall of the existing side extension/garage, and approximately 3 metres from the rear wall of the original dwellinghouse. The extension would have a flat roof and would measure approximately 3 metres in height. The extension would include one lantern rooflight in its centre. Officers consider that the proposed single storey rear extension would appear proportionate and subordinate to the dwellinghouse, and it is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments: The principal properties to consider in relation to amenity are No. 34 and No. 38 Woodlands Avenue. In relation to No. 36 Woodland Avenue, this neighbouring property benefits from a single storey rear extension, in a conservatory style with windows on all elevations. The application proposes an extension of approximately 5.9 metres on the boundary with this neighbouring property. Whilst the proposed extension may result in some loss of sunlight to the closest habitable room window at this neighbouring extension, as other windows facilitate this habitable room, Officers consider the impact on levels of sunlight to No. 34 Woodlands Avenue to be acceptable. As no windows are proposed facing this neighbouring property, the application would not result in a loss of privacy to No. 34 Woodlands Avenue. Similarly due to the scale of the proposed development, Officers consider that the proposal would not result in an overbearing impact.  In relation to No. 38 Woodlands Avenue, as the extension is set away from the boundary with this neighbouring property, in conjunction with the scale of the proposed development and that no windows are proposed facing this property, Officers consider that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of No. 38 Woodlands Avenue by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Paragraphs 199 to 208 of the NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements. When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and the more important the asset, the greater the weight should be). This is irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance. Officers Comments: The Berg Estate Local Area of Special Character constitutes a non-designated heritage asset. The significance of the The Berg Estate Local Area of Special Character can be summarised as an area of varying scale, design, plot styles and time periods. As it is considered that the proposed development would have an acceptable impact on the character and appearance of the dwellinghouse, with the development situated to the rear of the site, Officers consider the proposed development would not cause harm to the cultural significance of The Berg Estate Local Area of Special Character. Policy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy DM9 of the Council's LDF Core Strategy (2012) states that new development must comply with local car parking standards in order that it does not contribute to congestion or compromise highway safety. Policy DM10 supports this stance.Officers Comments: The application proposes the conversion of an existing garage into a habitable room. To accommodate modern vehicles, proposed new garages should meet the required dimensions as recommended by Appendix 5 of the Sustainable Transport SPD, measuring 3 metres in width and 5.3 metres in depth internally. The existing garage would not meet the minimum required internal garage dimensions for one vehicle, and therefore the removal of this garage would not impact the parking provision on site. Furthermore, it is considered that the remaining hardstanding is of an adequate size to accommodate two off-street car parking spaces. Whilst this level of provision would be in excess of the maximum standards set out in the London Plan, this issue would not warrant a reason for refusal as it is reflective of the existing situation. London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

--- Officer Report ---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.The Development Plan comprises:The London Plan 2021;RBK Core Strategy 2012;Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,The South London Waste Plan 2012.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Application SiteThe site comprises a residential building in C2 use.Proposal Demolition of rear extension and erection of part rear ground floor extension, first floor rear extension and roof extension in association with conversion from Residential Care facility (Use Class C2) into 5no. self-contained residential flats (Use Class C3) with associated bin store, cycle provision and landscapingConsultation 26 objections received. The objections can be summarised as follows- Car park issues- Excessive height or bulk of buildings- Loss of light/Sunlight- Privacy- Access or traffic problems- Inappropriate design/layout- Effects on trees- Fumes- Noise- Unacceptable or incompatible useNeighbourhood Traffic Engineer: Object on grounds of parking pressure and lack of parking beat survey.AssessmentThe proposed development would result in the loss of C2 housing and the applicant has provided no reasoned justification for its loss or supporting evidence that there is no longer a need for its provision. As such the proposal would be contrary to Policy H12 of the London Plan and Policy DM14 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012.The proposal would provide a net increase of 5 residential units (at a time when the borough does not have a 5 year housing supply)including 3 x 3 bed units capable of being used as family accommodation and more than 30% of the units. In real terms the net increase would be 2 residential units with a 6 bed care home which the current C2 use provides equating to 3 open market C3 units. The units would meet the internal and external floorspace and amenity space standards. The units would be of a practical layout and include provision for refuse and recycling and cycle parking provision. It is considered that the the proposed development by virtue of its size, siting and design would create a dominant and overbearing incongruous feature that would be visually intrusive in the streetscene and the private views of the site from the rear of the neighbouring properties creating an unnecessary sense of enclosure to the neighbouring properties and detract from the character and appearance of the host proeprty and the surrounding area. The proposal would not be in accordance with policy CS8 and DM10 of the Councils adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012.The proposed development would increase demand for on street parking and exacerbating existing on street car parking presures and the applicant has failed to provide any off street parking to mitigate this or evidence that there is capcity on street by way of a parking beat survey and as such the proposal is likely to prejudice highway safety. The proposal therefore would not accord Para 111 of the NPPF and Policy DM9 and DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012.There are no trees proposed to be removed as a result of the proposed development. The applicantion is not supported by a daylight/sunlight assessment and there is concern that the properties agjacent the application site could suffer an adverse loss of daylight/sunlight to the detriment of the existing living conditions of neighbouring occupiers. The siting, distance, from and orientation of the buildig and habitable room widows in relation to neighbouring properties is such that it is considered that the proposed development would not have an adverse impact on the privacy or outlook of neighbouring occupiers. ConclusionIn conclusion, it is considered that the public benefits of providing 5 net C3 open market units including 2 family sized units is not outweighed by the disbenefits of losing specialist C2 housing and the proposals impacts on the character and appearance of the area and amenity of neighbouring occupiers and exacerbation of existing parking pressures on street. As such the proposed development is not considered to be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than not in accordance with the development plan.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal--- Informatives ---Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.

Consultations11no. surrounding properties were notified of the proposed development. One representation received in support of the proposals.Planning HistoryNo planning history recorded.ProposalThe application seeks full planning permission for the demolition of the existing conservatory and erection of single-storey rear extension. Conversion of existing garage to habitable space with associated changes to fenestration.  Installation of 1no front and 1no rear rooflights. Site and SurroundingsThe application site comprises of a two-storey detached dwellinghouse. The surrounding properties comprise of predominantly semi-detached two-storey dwellinghouses.The application site is not located within a Conservation Area and does not comprise of a statutory or locally listed building. Planning AssessmentThe key considerations in the assessment of this application are:-	Character and Appearance; -	The Impact upon Residential Amenity; -	The Impact upon Highways; and -	Fire SafetyCharacter and Appearance Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.The proposed single-storey rear extension would not be visible from the streetscene, contained to the rear. The proposals involve the demolition of the existing conservatory structure to the rear elevation and erection of a replacement single-storey rear extension to span the full width of the dwelling. The roof is shown to be of a pitch design. The extension would measure 7.5m in width, part 4m, part 3m in depth and have a maximum height of 3.5m.The extension would comply with Council's guidance on scale and design of single-storey rear extensions as outlined in Policy Guidance 33 of the Council's Residential Design SPD. The matching buff and red colour stock brick finish to the rear extension is considered acceptable, in keeping with the rear elevation of the host building. To the front elevation, the proposals seek to convert the integral garage into a habitable room with associated change from existing garage door to a window of a similar appearance to the existing main windows within the front elevation of the property. This is considered to be an acceptable alteration which would not result in any harm to the overall character and appearance of the host dwelling.The application additionally seeks the installation of one rooflight to the front roofslope and one rooflight to the rear roofslope. It is considered these would be acceptable additions to the roofslope in terms of their size, siting and design.Having regard to the above officers consider that there would be no material impact from the proposed development on the character and appearance of the area.Impact upon Residential AmenityPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 requires new development to deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity. Policy DM10 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012) is clear that development proposals should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The proposed rear single-storey extension would cause no significant increase in the loss of privacy, loss of daylight, sense of enclosure or loss of outlook to the adjoining properties. Officers note that there are no side-facing openings/glazing to the proposed rear extension towards the eastern boundary to give rise to overlooking or loss of privacy of the neighbouring property to the east (i.e. No. 20). Officers note that one small side window is proposed to the western side however this is not considered to result in any detrimental amenity issues given the separation distance and relationship to the application site of those nearest properties which front onto Connaught Road. The scale and design of the extension is such that it would comply with Council's guidance on such types of development. The alterations to the fenestration would not cause any materially harmful impacts to neighbouring amenity.Accordingly, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of residential amenity.Impact upon HighwaysPolicy DM10 of the Core Strategy states that proposals should have regard to local traffic conditions and highway safety and ensure that they are not adversely affected. The application involves the conversion of the integral garage space, although based on the existing floor plan, it does not appear to be of a size capable of fitting a modern car. Nevertheless, the area of hardstanding/driveway to the front of the property is of an adequate size to be used as a car parking space, and so the conversion would not result in the loss of a space that would impact upon highway safety.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development would accord with the relevant policies of the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), and Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Core Strategy (2012).The proposal by virtue of its scale, design and materiality is considered to be subservient to the host dwelling and would not result in harm to the character and appearance of the host dwelling or wider area. In addition, the proposals would not result in materially harmful impact to neighbouring amenity by way of overlooking, loss of light or sense of overbearing or enclosure. In addition adequate car parking space for the property would be retained, to the satisfaction of the Council.Recommendation:That planning permission be GRANTED
The proposed site is categorised as a flat in our record, please confirm the ownership certificate A is correct, otherwise please amend the application form with the correct owenship certificate.

We require the location plan with red outline to show the proposed site, the red outline in the submitted location plan has main road also, please do not include main road within a red outline. An example of a location plan can be found in www.publicaccess.kingston.gov.uk/online-applications/
Note: It is to the applicants benefit to provide as much supporting information as possible for the proposal such as plans, elevations, photographs and supporting documents
The proposed site is categorised as a flat, please confirm the replacement windows are for flat no 3 or whole building.

For the avoidance of doubt, please confirm the description 'Replacement of 4nos front single glazed sash timber windows with 4 double-glazed sash timber windows, 1no side single glazed sash timber window with a double-glazed PVC or timber window, 1no rear sealed bathroom window with an openable window.'

The submitted block plans do not show adjoining properties to the side and rear. Please provide a copy of proposed block plan drawn at an identified standard metric scale (such as 1:200 or 1:500) showing the proposed works (hatched or shaded) in relation to the existing dwelling, site boundaries and any outbuildings on site.  The block plan must show the direction of North and should also show adjoining properties to the side and rear and those opposite in full outline.
